title: Treatment Options for Advanced Basal Cell Carcinoma
author: Rachel Reiff Ellis

content: Surgery, radiation, and medications you put on your skin are the most common treatments for basal cell carcinoma (BCC). But sometimes they don’t work as well on advanced BCC.
The best treatment for you will depend on several factors, including:
Your doctor may recommend more surgeries, medications you take by mouth, or other options. They should also ask what you’d like to do and go over treatment cost. Here’s what you need to know.
bullets: How far the cancer has spread
Whether you’ve had treatment for the tumor before

content_blocks.text: Surgery, radiation, and medications you put on your skin are the most common treatments for basal cell carcinoma (BCC). But sometimes they don’t work as well on advanced BCC.
The best treatment for you will depend on several factors, including:
associated_bullets: How far the cancer has spread
Whether you’ve had treatment for the tumor before

content_blocks.text: Your doctor may recommend more surgeries, medications you take by mouth, or other options. They should also ask what you’d like to do and go over treatment cost. Here’s what you need to know.

sections.heading: Excisional Surgery
content: This is when your doctor numbs your skin where the cancer is, then cuts the tumor out with a surgical knife. They’ll also cut off some of the nearby skin that’s normal. Your doctor will stitch the opening up. You’ll have a scar where the tumor used to be.

This is a good treatment choice when your tumor is small, has very clear borders, and is caught early. Your doctor will likely send the normal tissue to a lab to see if it has any cancer cells. If it doesn’t, this tells your doctor the surgery got rid of all of the tumor.

content_blocks.text: This is when your doctor numbs your skin where the cancer is, then cuts the tumor out with a surgical knife. They’ll also cut off some of the nearby skin that’s normal. Your doctor will stitch the opening up. You’ll have a scar where the tumor used to be.

This is a good treatment choice when your tumor is small, has very clear borders, and is caught early. Your doctor will likely send the normal tissue to a lab to see if it has any cancer cells. If it doesn’t, this tells your doctor the surgery got rid of all of the tumor.

sections.heading: Mohs Surgery
content: In this special type of surgery, a doctor takes out cancer tissue layer by layer, freezing each one as they go. They look at each layer under a microscope to search for cancer cells before moving on to the next one. This helps them make sure they get the whole tumor while easing scarring on your skin.
Doctors often use this surgery for advanced BCC that:
Usually this procedure is best for skin on or surrounding your:
Your doctor may use stitches to close up your surgical site or leave it to heal on its own.
bullets: Has a high risk of coming back

sections.heading: Radiation Therapy
content: Radiation uses low-energy X-ray beams to kill your tumor’s cancer cells. There’s no cutting involved, so you don’t need anesthesia to numb the area. You’ll likely need several sessions of radiation for it to work.

content_blocks.text: Radiation uses low-energy X-ray beams to kill your tumor’s cancer cells. There’s no cutting involved, so you don’t need anesthesia to numb the area. You’ll likely need several sessions of radiation for it to work.

content: Radiation isn’t as clear-cut as other forms of treatment. Your doctor may choose it if:
You may get radiation along with other treatments. For example, if your tumor is touching nerves, your doctor may use radiation after surgery to try and make sure they get all of the cancer.
Radiation side effects can include:
bullets: Your tumor is hard to treat with surgery
You can’t have surgery because of your age or other health issues
Skin irritation, redness, blistering, or peeling
Hair loss in the area getting radiation
Damage to salivary (spit) glands or teeth when radiation is done nearby

content_blocks.text: Radiation isn’t as clear-cut as other forms of treatment. Your doctor may choose it if:
associated_bullets: Your tumor is hard to treat with surgery
You can’t have surgery because of your age or other health issues

Damage to salivary (spit) glands or teeth when radiation is done nearby

sections.heading: Chemotherapy
content: You may be able to treat advanced BCC with topical chemotherapy if your advanced BCC hasn’t spread to other parts of your body. Two options are:

These are lotions you apply that kill cancerous cells. You use them for 3 to 6 weeks. They only treat cancers near the surface of your skin. If your cancer is deep, topical chemotherapy won’t get rid of all of it.

content_blocks.text: You may be able to treat advanced BCC with topical chemotherapy if your advanced BCC hasn’t spread to other parts of your body. Two options are:

These are lotions you apply that kill cancerous cells. You use them for 3 to 6 weeks. They only treat cancers near the surface of your skin. If your cancer is deep, topical chemotherapy won’t get rid of all of it.

content: You may need chemotherapy drugs through an IV if your advanced BCC is metastatic, or has spread to other parts of your body. These powerful drugs kill rapidly growing cells. They can cause many side effects, including:
Chemotherapy is rarely used for advanced BCC. Instead, doctors typically choose targeted drug therapies.
Targeted drug therapy

Advanced BCC that has spread deep into your skin or keeps coming back may respond best to targeted therapy. You take this medication by mouth. It finds the proteins, or abnormal genes or cells, that mark skin cancer cells. The drug then blocks signals for these cells to grow.
There are two approved targeted therapy drugs for treating advanced BCC:

content: These drugs are best for rare cases of metastatic basal cell carcinoma and skin cancer that’s deep or has come back a lot. Doctors usually suggest these drugs if surgery and radiation aren’t an option.
They may cause some side effects, including:

meta_description: Learn more about targeted drug therapy, chemotherapy, surgery, and other options for treating advanced basal cell carcinoma.
